clusters.title: Key US and regional mediators join talks in push to end Gaza war
clusters.neutral_headline: Mediators Join Gaza Talks Aiming for Ceasefire

items.title: Key US and regional mediators join talks in push to end Gaza war
items.standfirst: Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner's arrival in Egypt comes after Hamas submitted a list of Palestinian prisoners it wants Israel to release in exchange for hostages.
items.content: Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner's arrival in Egypt comes after Hamas submitted a list of Palestinian prisoners it wants Israel to release in exchange for hostages.

items.title: Witkoff and Kushner join Gaza talks as Hamas says hostage and prisoner lists exchanged
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump’s special envoy Steve Witkoff and son-in-law Jared Kushner will join Gaza ceasefire talks in Egypt on Wednesday, as Hamas said the two sides had taken an initial step toward a key point of the U.S. plan to end the devastating war.
items.content: President Donald Trump’s special envoy Steve Witkoff and son-in-law Jared Kushner will join Gaza ceasefire talks in Egypt on Wednesday, as Hamas said the two sides had taken an initial step toward a key point of the U.S. plan to end the devastating war.

items.title: Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner set to join Israel-Hamas talks in Egypt

items.content: Senior officials from Qatar and Turkey also expected to attend in push for breakthrough over Donald Trump’s peace plan

items.title: Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner set to join Israel-Hamas talks in Egypt
items.standfirst: Senior officials from Qatar and Turkey also expected to attend in push for breakthrough over Donald Trump’s peace plan
items.content: Senior officials from Qatar and Turkey also expected to attend in push for breakthrough over Donald Trump’s peace plan

items.title: Top U.S. officials join Gaza talks as Hamas voices optimism
items.standfirst: Hamas and Egypt voiced new optimism Wednesday as President Donald Trump's envoy and key mediators joined talks to end Israel's war in Gaza.“A spirit of optimism prevails among all,” the militant group said after it submitted a list of Palestinian prisoners to be released in exchange for Israeli hostages under the U.S. plan.
items.content: Hamas and Egypt voiced new optimism Wednesday as President Donald Trump's envoy and key mediators joined talks to end Israel's war in Gaza.“A spirit of optimism prevails among all,” the militant group said after it submitted a list of Palestinian prisoners to be released in exchange for Israeli hostages under the U.S. plan.

items.title: US, Qatar, Turkey to join third day of Gaza peace talks in Egypt
items.standfirst: Qatar's prime minister and senior delegates from the United States and Turkey will join Hamas and Israeli negotiators on Wednesday for a third day of talks aimed at ending the Gaza war. France24 correspondent Noga Tarnopolsky reports the latest.
items.content: Qatar's prime minister and senior delegates from the United States and Turkey will join Hamas and Israeli negotiators on Wednesday for a third day of talks aimed at ending the Gaza war. France24 correspondent Noga Tarnopolsky reports the latest.

items.title: Gaza: Hamas official says hostage and prisoner lists exchanged with Israel
items.standfirst: Hamas negotiators and Israel have exchanged lists of prisoners and hostages who would be released should a deal be reached during the ongoing Gaza ceasefire talks in Egypt, senior Hamas official Taher Al-Nounou said on Wednesday. Indirect negotiations between Israel and Hamas are being held at the Red Sea resort town of Sharm El-Sheikh, based on a 20-point plan proposed by US President Donald Trump last month. France24 correspondent Noga Tarnopolsky reports from Jerusalem.
items.content: Hamas negotiators and Israel have exchanged lists of prisoners and hostages who would be released should a deal be reached during the ongoing Gaza ceasefire talks in Egypt, senior Hamas official Taher Al-Nounou said on Wednesday. Indirect negotiations between Israel and Hamas are being held at the Red Sea resort town of Sharm El-Sheikh, based on a 20-point plan proposed by US President Donald Trump last month. France24 correspondent Noga Tarnopolsky reports from Jerusalem.

items.title: Gaza live: Hostage and prisoner lists exchanged, Hamas official says

Follow our liveblog for the latest developments.

items.title: US delegation led by Steve Witkoff due to arrive in Egypt for Gaza talks
items.standfirst: White House says it is important ‘that we get this done quickly’ as indirect talks restart in Sharm el-SheikhA US delegation led by envoy Steve Witkoff is expected to join talks in Egypt on Wednesday to reinforce President Donald Trump’s involvement in the newly restarted negotiations between Hamas and Israel aimed at ending the war in Gaza.The indirect talks at Sharm el-Sheikh, the Egyptian resort city on the Red Sea, entered their second day on the second anniversary of the Hamas surprise attack into Israel that triggered the bloody conflict. Continue reading...
items.content: White House says it is important ‘that we get this done quickly’ as indirect talks restart in Sharm el-SheikhA US delegation led by envoy Steve Witkoff is expected to join talks in Egypt on Wednesday to reinforce President Donald Trump’s involvement in the newly restarted negotiations between Hamas and Israel aimed at ending the war in Gaza.The indirect talks at Sharm el-Sheikh, the Egyptian resort city on the Red Sea, entered their second day on the second anniversary of the Hamas surprise attack into Israel that triggered the bloody conflict. Continue reading...

ai_summary: US envoy Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner joined talks in Egypt.
Hamas and Israel exchanged lists of prisoners and hostages.
Senior officials from Qatar and Turkey also attended the talks.
Hamas expressed optimism regarding the talks' progress.
The talks aim to end the ongoing war in Gaza.

items.standfirst: The 2025 Nobel Prize in Chemistry was on Wednesday awarded to scientists Susumu Kitagawa, Richard Robson and Omar Yaghi "for the development of metal–organic frameworks", the award-giving body announced.
items.content: The 2025 Nobel Prize in Chemistry was on Wednesday awarded to scientists Susumu Kitagawa, Richard Robson and Omar Yaghi "for the development of metal–organic frameworks", the award-giving body announced.

clusters.title: Comey due in court over Justice Department case accusing him of lying to Congress – US politics live
clusters.neutral_headline: White House Memo Suggests No Back Pay for Furloughed Workers

items.title: Comey due in court over Justice Department case accusing him of lying to Congress – US politics live
items.standfirst: Former FBI director expected to plead not guilty in case that has amplified concerns that the department is being used to pursue Trump’s enemiesThe White House’s office of management and budget (OMB) is arguing that federal workers who are furloughed amid the ongoing government shutdown are not entitled to back pay.In a draft memo first obtained by Axios, OMB argued that an amendment to the Government Employee Fair Treatment Act (GEFTA) of 2019 would not guarantee furloughed workers back pay and that said funds must be set aside by Congress. Continue reading...
items.content: Former FBI director expected to plead not guilty in case that has amplified concerns that the department is being used to pursue Trump’s enemiesThe White House’s office of management and budget (OMB) is arguing that federal workers who are furloughed amid the ongoing government shutdown are not entitled to back pay.In a draft memo first obtained by Axios, OMB argued that an amendment to the Government Employee Fair Treatment Act (GEFTA) of 2019 would not guarantee furloughed workers back pay and that said funds must be set aside by Congress. Continue reading...

items.title: Draft White House memo suggests furloughed government workers are not guaranteed pay
items.standfirst: President Trump was questioned on Tuesday about whether federal workers will receive back pay for salaries lost due to the government shutdown. The questions came after a draft White House memo suggested furloughed federal workers and employees working without pay are not guaranteed compensation. CBS News White House reporter Aaron Navarro has more.
items.content: President Trump was questioned on Tuesday about whether federal workers will receive back pay for salaries lost due to the government shutdown. The questions came after a draft White House memo suggested furloughed federal workers and employees working without pay are not guaranteed compensation. CBS News White House reporter Aaron Navarro has more.

items.title: White House floats no back pay for some furloughed federal workers despite 2019 law
items.standfirst: A new draft White House memo suggests a 2019 law signed by President Trump that guarantees that federal employees get paid after a shutdown ends would not apply to furloughed workers.
items.content: A new draft White House memo suggests a 2019 law signed by President Trump that guarantees that federal employees get paid after a shutdown ends would not apply to furloughed workers.(Image credit: Anna Moneymaker)

items.title: Five detained after alleged assassination attempt on Ecuador's Noboa
items.standfirst: Ecuadorean President Daniel Noboa’s car was surrounded by about 500 protesters hurling rocks as he arrived for an event in Canar province, a minister said on Tuesday, adding there were “signs of bullet damage” on the vehicle. Noboa was unharmed and five people were detained, the minister added. Ellen Gainsford reports.
items.content: Ecuadorean President Daniel Noboa’s car was surrounded by about 500 protesters hurling rocks as he arrived for an event in Canar province, a minister said on Tuesday, adding there were “signs of bullet damage” on the vehicle. Noboa was unharmed and five people were detained, the minister added. Ellen Gainsford reports.

clusters.title: Outgoing French PM hopeful for concessions to avoid snap elections
clusters.neutral_headline: French PM Seeks Consensus to Avoid Snap Elections

items.title: Outgoing French PM hopeful for concessions to avoid snap elections
items.standfirst: Sébastien Lecornu continues meetings with party leaders in effort to pass budget and avoid further political instability• Europe live – latest updatesFrance’s caretaker prime minister, Sébastien Lecornu, has said his talks with various party leaders had revealed a “willingness” to pass a budget by the end of the year and that snap parliamentary elections were now looking less likely.“This willingness creates a momentum and a convergence, obviously, which make the possibilities of a dissolution more remote,” he said in a brief address on Wednesday from the courtyard of Matignon Palace, the prime minister’s residence, in Paris. Continue reading...
items.content: Sébastien Lecornu continues meetings with party leaders in effort to pass budget and avoid further political instability• Europe live – latest updatesFrance’s caretaker prime minister, Sébastien Lecornu, has said his talks with various party leaders had revealed a “willingness” to pass a budget by the end of the year and that snap parliamentary elections were now looking less likely.“This willingness creates a momentum and a convergence, obviously, which make the possibilities of a dissolution more remote,” he said in a brief address on Wednesday from the courtyard of Matignon Palace, the prime minister’s residence, in Paris. Continue reading...

items.title: Socialist party leader Olivier Faure says his camp wants a real left-wing government
items.standfirst: Socialist Party leader Olivier Faure said there is no guarantee that France’s pension reform will be suspended, despite discussions with caretaker Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu. He also stated that the Socialist Party cannot support the government's current budget proposal. Faure made these remarks following his meeting with Lecornu, who began a two-day series of talks with political parties after resigning from his post on Monday morning. France24's Clovis Casali tells us the latest from the Hotel de Matignon in Paris.
items.content: Socialist Party leader Olivier Faure said there is no guarantee that France’s pension reform will be suspended, despite discussions with caretaker Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu. He also stated that the Socialist Party cannot support the government's current budget proposal. Faure made these remarks following his meeting with Lecornu, who began a two-day series of talks with political parties after resigning from his post on Monday morning. France24's Clovis Casali tells us the latest from the Hotel de Matignon in Paris.

items.title: French Socialist Party say there are no guarantee pension reform will be suspended
items.standfirst: Socialist Party leader Olivier Faure said there is no guarantee that France’s pension reform will be suspended, despite discussions with caretaker Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu. He also stated that the Socialist Party cannot support the government's current budget proposal. Faure made these remarks following his meeting with Lecornu, who began a two-day series of talks with political parties after resigning from his post on Monday morning. Here's the replay of his speech.
items.content: Socialist Party leader Olivier Faure said there is no guarantee that France’s pension reform will be suspended, despite discussions with caretaker Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu. He also stated that the Socialist Party cannot support the government's current budget proposal. Faure made these remarks following his meeting with Lecornu, who began a two-day series of talks with political parties after resigning from his post on Monday morning. Here's the replay of his speech.

items.title: France: Outgoing PM Lecornu says consensus emerging to have budget by year end
items.standfirst: In a Wednesday morning address, France’s outgoing Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu expressed hope for securing a budget by the end of 2025 and noted that the prospect of dissolving parliament appeared increasingly unlikely. Having resigned on Monday after widespread rejection of his newly appointed cabinet, Lecornu is set to meet with representatives from the Socialist, Green, and Communist parties later in an effort to form a coalition government. France24's Clovis Casali tells us the latest.
items.content: In a Wednesday morning address, France’s outgoing Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu expressed hope for securing a budget by the end of 2025 and noted that the prospect of dissolving parliament appeared increasingly unlikely. Having resigned on Monday after widespread rejection of his newly appointed cabinet, Lecornu is set to meet with representatives from the Socialist, Green, and Communist parties later in an effort to form a coalition government. France24's Clovis Casali tells us the latest.

items.title: Outgoing French PM hopes to have a budget by end of 2025, dissolution 'looks more remote'
items.standfirst: Caretaker French Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu stated that the likelihood of dissolving parliament now appears remote, following a series of discussions with various political parties. He noted that these talks revealed a general willingness among parties to pass a budget by the end of the year, which, according to him, has created a sense of momentum and political convergence, reducing the chances of dissolution. Lecornu also mentioned that he would meet with President Emmanuel Macron later Wednesday evening to discuss the outcomes of these consultations. France24's Clovis Casali tells us the latest from the Hotel Matignon, in Paris.
items.content: Caretaker French Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu stated that the likelihood of dissolving parliament now appears remote, following a series of discussions with various political parties. He noted that these talks revealed a general willingness among parties to pass a budget by the end of the year, which, according to him, has created a sense of momentum and political convergence, reducing the chances of dissolution. Lecornu also mentioned that he would meet with President Emmanuel Macron later Wednesday evening to discuss the outcomes of these consultations. France24's Clovis Casali tells us the latest from the Hotel Matignon, in Paris.

items.title: France: Outgoing Prime Minister Lecornu makes address after holding coalition talks
items.standfirst: In an address on Wednesday morning, France’s outgoing prime minister Sébastien Lecornu said he hoped to have a budget by the end of 2025, adding that dissolution of the country's parliament was looking "more remote". Lecornu, who resigned on Monday following broad rejection of his new cabinet, will later meet with socialists, greens and communists in a bid to form a coalition government.
items.content: In an address on Wednesday morning, France’s outgoing prime minister Sébastien Lecornu said he hoped to have a budget by the end of 2025, adding that dissolution of the country's parliament was looking "more remote". Lecornu, who resigned on Monday following broad rejection of his new cabinet, will later meet with socialists, greens and communists in a bid to form a coalition government.

items.title: Live: No guarantee pension reform will be suspended, says French Socialist party
items.standfirst: French Socialist Party leader Olivier Faure said Wednesday that there were no guarantees that the suspension to France's controversial pension reform would go ahead, following talks with caretaker Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu. In an address from Matignon earlier in the day, Lecornu said he hoped to have a budget by the end of 2025, adding that dissolution of the country's parliament was looking "more remote". Follow our live blog for all the latest developments.
items.content: French Socialist Party leader Olivier Faure said Wednesday that there were no guarantees that the suspension to France's controversial pension reform would go ahead, following talks with caretaker Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu. In an address from Matignon earlier in the day, Lecornu said he hoped to have a budget by the end of 2025, adding that dissolution of the country's parliament was looking "more remote". Follow our live blog for all the latest developments.

ai_summary: Outgoing PM Lecornu is hopeful for concessions.
Lecornu is meeting with party leaders.
The goal is to pass a budget.
Snap elections are looking less likely.
The Socialist Party has concerns.

items.content: Spot gold prices on Wednesday hit $4,000 for the first time as safe‑haven demand continues to drive the yellow metal's prices higher. The latest rise "likely reflects safe‑haven demand tied to the U.S. government shutdown and the resignation of Sebastien Lecornu as France's prime minister," Vivek…

items.title: Gold price tops $4,000 for first time as investors seek safe haven
items.standfirst: Precious metal having biggest rally since 1970s amid political uncertainty in US, France and JapanBusiness live – latest updatesThe price of gold has risen above $4,000 (£2,980) per ounce for the first time as investors continue to seek a safe place to put their money at a time of global political and economic uncertainty.The spot price of gold – the real-time market value of gold and viewed as the global benchmark – reached $4,031.54 at 8am in London on Wednesday morning, after climbing 1.2% during early trading. Continue reading...
items.content: Precious metal having biggest rally since 1970s amid political uncertainty in US, France and JapanBusiness live – latest updatesThe price of gold has risen above $4,000 (£2,980) per ounce for the first time as investors continue to seek a safe place to put their money at a time of global political and economic uncertainty.The spot price of gold – the real-time market value of gold and viewed as the global benchmark – reached $4,031.54 at 8am in London on Wednesday morning, after climbing 1.2% during early trading. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Spot gold prices hit $4,000 for the first time.
The rise is due to safe-haven demand.
Uncertainty is driving the price increase.
The US government shutdown is a factor.
The French PM's resignation is also a factor.

clusters.title: Chad cuts ties with Prince Harry's 'disrespectful' wildlife charity
clusters.neutral_headline: Chad Cuts Ties with Prince Harry's 'Disrespectful' Wildlife Charity

items.title: Chad cuts ties with Prince Harry's 'disrespectful' wildlife charity
items.standfirst: A charity partially run by Prince Harry has had its mandate for managing wildlife reserves in Chad removed by the country's government.
items.content: A charity partially run by Prince Harry has had its mandate for managing wildlife reserves in Chad removed by the country's government.

items.title: Chad cuts ties with wildlife charity linked to Prince Harry
items.standfirst: The government says the charity African Parks displayed an arrogant and disrespectful attitude.
items.content: The government says the charity African Parks displayed an arrogant and disrespectful attitude.

ai_summary: Chad removed the charity's mandate.
The charity is partially run by Prince Harry.
The government cited an arrogant attitude.
The charity is African Parks.
The decision affects wildlife reserves.

clusters.title: The government shutdown is snarling air travel. Officials say it could get worse
clusters.neutral_headline: Government Shutdown Causes Air Travel Delays

items.title: The government shutdown is snarling air travel. Officials say it could get worse
items.standfirst: A dozen facilities saw air traffic control shortages on Monday, delaying flights at several airports. Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy blamed "a slight tick-up in sick calls" due to the shutdown.
items.content: A dozen facilities saw air traffic control shortages on Monday, delaying flights at several airports. Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy blamed "a slight tick-up in sick calls" due to the shutdown.(Image credit: Michael Nagle)

items.title: Flight delays as US air traffic controllers feel strain of government shutdown
items.standfirst: More than 6,000 US flights were delayed Monday as some airports temporarily closed amid staffing shortagesMajor US airports continued to see flight delays on Tuesday as air traffic control facilities struggle to maintain staffing amid the federal government shutdown.Shortages on Monday affected major airports around New York, Los Angeles and Denver on Monday, with over 6,000 flights delayed across the US. Continue reading...
items.content: More than 6,000 US flights were delayed Monday as some airports temporarily closed amid staffing shortagesMajor US airports continued to see flight delays on Tuesday as air traffic control facilities struggle to maintain staffing amid the federal government shutdown.Shortages on Monday affected major airports around New York, Los Angeles and Denver on Monday, with over 6,000 flights delayed across the US. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The government shutdown is snarling air travel.
Air traffic control shortages are occurring.
Flight delays are happening at several airports.
Transportation Secretary blamed sick calls.
Major airports are experiencing delays.
